title: Covid-19 Tools
description: In late February when the realization of a looming pandemic hit, I started building several internal tools for our newsroom to help track the spread. || I built one of the first API's that scraped and aggregated multiple sources of data into a consistent format useful for ingestion into other apps and analysis programs.|| Several maps sprang up quickly, most notably the one built by Johns Hopkins University. But the lack of normalization for per capita rates meant that they didn't tell the full story. So I built an interactive one that normalized confirmed rates and deaths per county by total and by the last 48 hours. This helped our team get a better handle on what hotspots were occuring and where. || Testing data was available, but fragmented and not easily compared so I built a chart that helped visualize how and if the curve was flattening relative to any state and its surrounding states.
images: cv19_map.jpg, cv19_map_2.jpg, cv19_map_3.jpg, cv19_chart.jpg, cv19_chart_2.jpg, cv19_api.jpg

title: Interactive ‘Crazy Wall’
description: The crazy wall was an idea conceived and executed by our design studio to combine research from multiple reporters and help visualize the flow of how a Mexican cartel infiltrated the US. The wall was a physical 12x8 foot display that had a special rig constructed in order to scan it in with a DSLR camera and stitch the pieces back together. || The problem is that the digital version is so large and so detailed that it simply cannot be shared online in it's full size. I wrote the processing script that slices this massive gigapixel image into a series of tiles so that in can be loaded into LeafletJS so the user can zoom and pan just like a geographic map. || As part of the develpment process, I created a special "collaboration mode" that previewed the final result while also allowing reporters to add, edit, and delete annotations on top of it. These annotations show as markers and help give some context behind particular parts of the map.

title: Matt Bevin Pardon Database
description: In the fall of 2019 former Kentucky governor Matt Bevin made a series of questionable pardons and commutations of convicted offenders. We were tipped off before the full list of the pardons were available on the Secretary of State's website. || The first thing that I did was to write a program that parses and dumps the contents of the pardons into a shared spreadsheet as they became available. This spreadsheet was distributed among our newsroom for use on follow up and analysis in stories. || I also took the initiative to quickly build a public facing database to help enhance our coverage. The Courier Journal newsroom went on to win the Pulitzer Prize for Breaking News Reporting for coverage of this story.

title: Election Results Analysis
description: Over the years of covering election results I've created several quick turn graphics and interactive maps, usually on election night while waiting for results to come in. Many of these focus on county or precinct level data.

title: Election Results
description: Covering results on election night can be a tricky thing. Data is available from multiple sources, in different formats, and often times with different update intervals. || I covered election results between 2013 and 2019. I quickly realized the need to automate collection and display of this data and wrote a set of tools I call ELX. || The first component to ELX is a backend tool that creates and manages a data model. This model is then updated from different scrapers. A final model is output by looking at the most up to date data available. || The second part of ELX is the frontend that users see. The interface constantly updates its number throughout the night and animations occur showing numbers counting up, bar charts slowing easing outwards, and the order of who's currently ahead in a race smoothly transitioning into place.

title: K-PREP Test Scores
description: Each year the Kentucky Department of Education releases a very large data dump of performance metrics related to testing and school diversity. I extract the primary information down into a searchable database for public use.

title: Kentucky Jeopardy Quiz
description: One of our producers came up with the idea to do a Jeopardy style quiz based on actual questions about Kentucky that have been featured on the show. This was a quick turnaround piece built from a reusable quiz template that I developed from scratch.

title: Metro Council Tax Proposal
description: In 2019 controversial proposal to increase taxes on some types of insurance premiums in Louisville led to a uncertainty and a split between metro council members. || There was a lot of speculation at the time about how council members were going to vote and so this was a quick turn interactive designed to show the state of sentiment at that time. It was updated over the period of a week as we obtained new information. This also includes a lookup tool that allows you to lookup your council person by address.

title: Austin Rising Series Landing Page
description: The Austin Rising series looks at a small town in Indiana and it's struggles to overcome one of the worst HIV outbreaks in the midwest. || Our design studio produced both mockups and style guides which I then translated to the web. I built the landing page as well as created custom web components in Polymer to style the individual stories.

title: JCPS Elementary Suspension Lookup
description: At the end of 2018, JCPS elementary school suspensions were increasing by an alarming rate. They also seemed to disproportionately affect black students by a wide margin. || Being able to show data for 92 individual elementary schools in a single article presented a challenge. I quickly created this data driven interactive chart to allow readers to search every school in the county.

title: Louisville Sewer Collapses
description: We requested data from Metroplitan Sewer District and mapped it in an attempt to show just how and where sewer collapses were happing in the city. I also used GIS vector data from LOJIC and combined that with data of the sewer lines ages to build the heat overlay.

title: Kentucky License Quiz
description: There was a lot of confusion about Kentucky's Real ID rollout and so rather than doing a standard "X things you need to know" style article, we created an interactive flowchart that helped people understand what ID they needed and why.

title: MMA Investigation Landing Page
description: In 2017, lax regulations in the local amateur MMA circuit contributed to the death of a contender. This quick scrollytelling piece and accompanying database of states was designed to be the intro to the main story.

title: Abandoned Vehicle Complaints Map
description: Quick turnaround map to show the depth of abandoned vehicles in Louisville from 311 data.

title: Kentucky Lynchings Map
description: In 2018 a memorial in Montgomery Alabama was unveiled by the Equal Justic Initiative to honor victims of slavery and lynching. We wanted to localize this story but after a back and forth with their director we were not able to obtain any information about the individual victims included in the memorial. || We decided to do the research ourselves. I started by writing a scraper for the University of Washingtons database on lynching and filtering out by Kentucky. We also did some research and clarified some of the narratives using our own archives. The result was an interactive map of known lynchings in Kentucky by county.

title: Kentucky Derby Headlines
description: I really wanted to build a quick turn visual piece that explores the evolution of the front page of the Courier Journal announcing the winner of the Derby through history. This page uses a scraper that I built to interface with Newspapers.com's non-public API to programatically pull the front page from a list of specified dates. The mapping library Leaflet is used to allow for smooth panning and zooming of the image so that users could read the full page.

title: Civil War Monument Map
description: In 2017 the removal of a handful of confederate monuments ignited a heated debate in the community. I decided to take a look at just how many civil war monuments existed in Kentucky. || This was a surprisingly difficult task as there was no list at the time. I scraped the pdf's from the National Park Service registry of monuments then used satellite imagery to track down the exact location of each one.

title: Louisville's Underground Tunnels
description: This was a fun piece we did for Halloween in 2017. Our resident "creepy place" expert Tom Novelly took photographers through six different tunnels in Louisville while documenting their history. I designed and built the entire page implementing a Mapbox map along with photo galleries and videos.

title: Hurricane Map
description: After Hurrican Irma hit in 2017, we put together a list of the top 10 costliest hurricanes in the US recorded so far. Rather than just put it in a table, I decided to jazz it up a little with scroll driven map.

title: Solar Eclipse Locator Map
description: Because the path of the eclipse totality ran through Kentucky, I took the initiative to build a locator map complete with details on where the eclipse would be viewable and when. || This site quickly went viral across the nation and broke newsroom Chartbeat records for having over 25k concurrent visitors at a time. To handle the load of unanticipated traffic, I quickly built a server side caching mechanism that took the load off of the geocoder and improved response times by 10x.

title: Voter Registration Quiz
description: In 2017 I built a private voter registration database using data from the SBoE in Kentucky. The intent was to use it alongside LexisNexis for research and verification purposes. || Our courts reporter thought it would be interesting to create a quiz to see if people could guess the party affiliation of notable Louisvillians. As a social experiment, I captured all answers to the quiz (anonymously) in order to track what the overall sentiment was towards each person.

title: Air Quality Map
description: A quick turn locator map of air quality by neighborhood complete with address lookup.

title: Suboxone Map
description: Quick turnaround map and data list showing rogue suboxone clinics across Kentucky.

title: Explorer Abuse List
description: This was the visual component to our investigative piece on the Explorer Scout abuse cases across America. I was asked to do a simple map but wanted to take a different approach with the data we had. || I felt that a standard locator map where people could simply look up the handful of instances in their own city and ignore the rest was a disservice. I wanted users to have to scroll through each and every case and narrative that had been uncovered so far. A subtle yet uncomfortable impression of just how long and widespread this abuse has been. While we didn't force users to go through this page to get to the main article, we clocked a very high engagment time on those who did.

title: This Day in History
description: This was a pet project of mine and probably one of my favorites that I have worked on. Not just the end result, but the challenge in getting there. || I'm a huge fan of the history of Kentucky and could spend hours at a time scanning through old newspapers. I thought it would be interesting if each day, after reading the current paper, I could also take a look back at one from the same day in a random year in the past. || To do this I reverse engineered Newspapers.com and their non-public API in order to be able to programatically pull images from archived papers. I then set up a script that would automatically load a new one from a random year every morning. The use of the Leaflet mapping library allows you to zoom and pan the image to help make it more readable.

title: Sewer Overflow Explainer
description: An guided interactive that explains how a combined sewer overflow works with a series of maps showing where they are located in Louisville.

title: Whiskeyrow Timeline
description: This was an experiment with using Mapbox GL to guide users on a path of the history of Whiskey Row.

title: It's Our Bridge
description: I did this interactive multimedia gallery in order to showcase the excellent work done by one of our photographers who chronicled the construction of the Abraham Lincoln bridge in Louisville. || While plenty of galleries existed detailing the manufacture of the bridge itself, the photos and audio here provide a human element by focusing on the individual laborers.

title: Public Defenders
description: This is a map of regions in Kentucky where public defenders work. Clicking on a region shows how in most cases their workload is way over the maximum threshold of recommended cases.

title: Structurally Deficient Bridge Map
description: A locator map of the 169 structurally deficient bridges in Louisville and the ratings assigned to them.

title: Flappy Card
description: In 2014 the game Flappy Bird for mobile platforms made headlines for deceptively simple yet addictive gameplay and the meteoric rise to fame of it's developer. || We attempted to do something fun over the holiday season by creating a clone with UofL's mascot. Our graphics designer provided the sprites and music while I handled all of the code and testing. || This was built over a period of only a few days and then added to our mobile app dedicated to coverage of UofL sports.

title: Tree Canopy Map
description: In 2014 we acquired two sets of data that gave an interesting look at the correlation between tree canopy coverage, and the urban heat island effect. This interactive map was also featured in a Politico article.

title: Effects of Heroin
description: Our team was tasked with building an interactive explainer about the effects of heroin on the body. Our graphics designer did the UI mockup and individual art elements and animations. I put it together writing a framework that allowed for an "x-ray effect" when moving the mouse over the image.

title: Malt Madness Contest
description: Malt Madness was a fun little project that pitted Kentuckiana breweries against each other in a NCAA tournament style bracket competition that readers could vote on. This was a sponsored product that generated revenue each year and coincided with a local event hosted by our spirits writer. || On top of the page design, I also designed and developed a reusable mobile friendly data driven bracket. We ran this each year between 2015 through 2018.
